title: Union Of India vs Samarendra Nath Mukherjee on 9 April, 2009
doc:
Union Of India vs Samarendra Nath Mukherjee on 9 April, 2009

Author: Indira Banerjee

Bench: Indira Banerjee

                                               1


ORDER SHEET                                                                  Sheet No...
                                  A.P. No. 251 of 2005

                         IN THE HIGH COURT AT CALCUTTA
                    ORDINARY ORIGINAL CIVIL JURISDICTION                           ORIGINAL
                              SIDE


                                                   In the matter of:


                                      UNION OF INDIA
                                          Vs.
                                  SAMARENDRA NATH MUKHERJEE
BEFORE:
The Hon'ble Justice
INDIRA BANERJEE.

Date: 09.04.2009
                                  Mr. N.R. Mukherjee .....for the Petitioner

                                  Mr. Moloy Kr. Ghosh.....for the Respondent


                                       JUDGMENT

This application under Sections 30 and 33 of the Arbitration Act, 1940, filed by Union of India, is for setting aside an award dated 31 st January 2005, of Rs.6,97,105.25p in favour of the respondent contractor, made and published by the sole arbitrator, Shree Dilip Kumar Basu, a retired Judge of this Court.

The petitioner floated a Tender Notice No. 568 A/89-90 on 5th March, 1990 inviting tenders for work in relation to renewal of points and crossings and ancillary work at the Sealdah South Yard of Eastern Railway.

2

Pursuant to the aforesaid tender enquiry, the respondent submitted its bid. The offer of the respondent was accepted by a letter dated 21st May, 1990, and the respondent was directed to commence work within ten days. A formal agreement in writing No.146 (i)(i) of 1990-1991 was executed by and between the petitioner and the respondent on 17th August, 1990.

The said agreement specifically provided that the General Conditions of Contract of the Eastern Railway as amended from time to time, would govern the contract between the petitioner and the respondent. The General Conditions of Contract inter alia contained an arbitration clause.

In the petition, it is alleged that the respondent, from the inception adopted a tardy and lethargic approach towards the contract work, and the time for completion of the contract had to be extended time and again, on account of the laches of the respondent. The contract was ultimately completed on or about 28 th May, 1991.

Upon completion of the contract work, a final bill, was prepared by the petitioner for Rs.62,969.05p. According to the petitioner, the respondent agreed to and confirmed the said final bill without raising any objection and the sum of Rs.62,969.05p was paid to the petitioner on 4 th September, 1991. It is alleged that the respondent accepted the aforesaid payment in full and final settlement of his dues. However, by a letter dated 6th November, 1995, the petitioner claimed Rs.15,92,249.10p towards his dues towards the contract work.

The respondent has, however, in his Affidavit-in-Opposition, categorically denied the allegations in the petition and in particular, the allegation of having accepted 3 Rs.62,969.05p in full and final settlement of his dues in respect of the contract. The respondent has further specifically referred to endorsements in the measurement book, as also a contemporaneous letter dated 6 th September, 1991, being part of the records of the arbitration proceedings.

The respondent invoked the arbitration clause, sought appointment of an arbitrator and filed a special suit under Section 20 of the Arbitration Act, 1940. By an order dated 19 th July, 1996 Sujit Kumar Sinha, J. disposed of the suit by referring the disputes to the arbitration of Mr. Gopal Chakraborty, a Senior Lawyer, who was appointed arbitrator.

The petitioner filed an appeal being APOT 569 of 1996, which was rejected by an order of the Division Bench dated 15 th October, 1996. The arbitrator Gopal Chakraborty entered into reference. About 185 sittings were held before the said arbitrator Gopal Chakraborty. Sri Gopal Chakraborty, however, died before conclusion of the arbitration proceedings.

After the death of Gopal Chakraborty, the respondent filed an application being G.A. No.3166 of 2003 for appointment of an arbitrator in place of Gopal Chakraborty. By an order dated 25 th November, 2003 in the said G.A. No.3166 of 2003 Sri Dilip Basu, a retired Judge of this Court was appointed arbitrator. The learned arbitrator held about 18 sittings.

The petitioner duly appeared before the learned arbitrator without protest. It would not be out of place to mention that the petitioner did not file any appeal in the Supreme 4 Court against the order of the Division Bench dated 15th October, 1996 affirming the order dated 19 th July, 1996 of the Single Judge in the Special Suit under Section 20, whereby the learned Single Judge appointed a senior lawyer as arbitrator.

The learned arbitrator made and published his award dated 31 st January, 2005 rejecting the counter-claim of the respondent and awarding Rs.6,97,105.25p in favour of the respondent which is under challenge in this application under Section 30 read with Section 33 of the Arbitration Act, 1940.

Mr. N.R. Mukherjee appearing on behalf of the petitioner submitted that the impugned award was without jurisdiction in as much as the arbitrator had not been appointed in accordance with clause 63(3)(a)(iii) of the General Conditions of Contract, which inter alia provides as follows:

"It is a term of this contract that no person other than a Gazetted Officer appointed by the General Manager as aforesaid has to act as an arbitrator or umpire and if for any reason that is not possible, the matter is not to be referred to arbitration at all."

Mr. Mukherjee submitted that no person other than a Gazetted Railway Officer could have been appointed arbitrator. The appointment of arbitrator being in contravention of the aforesaid provision, the award was a nullity, the same having been made by a coram non judice.

5

Mr. Mukherjee argued that if for any reason no gazetted railway officer could be appointed, the matter was not to be referred to arbitration at all. The dispute would have to be settled by recourse to a suit. Mr. Mukherjee argued that even a right decision by a wrong forum was no decision in the eye of law.

In support of his argument, that the impugned award was a nullity, Mr. Mukherjee cited the following judgments:

1. A. Mohammed Yunus vs. Food Corporation of India reported in 2000(7) Supreme Today 722.
2. Union of India vs. M.P. Gupta reported in (2004) 10 SCC 504.
3. Kiran Singh vs. Chaman Paswan reported in AIR 1954 SC 340.
4. Tarapore & Co. vs. State of M.P. reported in (1994) 3 SCC 521.
5. Smt. Jeevani Bano vs. Asha Arora reported in AIR 1997 Raj. 261.
6. Unreported judgment of the Supreme Court in Union of India vs. Krishna Kumar.
7. Unreported judgment of this Court in Union of India vs. Pam Developments Pvt.

Ltd.

Mr. Mukherjee next submitted that the impugned award was in any case, not a reasoned award. Mr. Mukherjee submitted that the learned arbitrator was obliged in terms of the contract, to give a reasoned award, in as much as the claim in the arbitration exceeded Rs.3,00,000/-.

The relevant clause provides as follows:

6

"In cases where the claim is more than 3 lakhs the arbitrators/umpire so appointed, as the case may be, shall give intelligible award (i.e. the reasoning leading to the award shall be stated) with the sums awarded separately on each individual item of dispute referred to arbitration."

A copy of such clause is annexed hereto and marked as Annexure B." Mr. Mukherjee submitted that the reasons were cryptic and no reasons in the eye of law. The arbitrator did not indicate the reasons for not accepting the submissions of the petitioners.

In support of his submission that an unreasoned award was liable to be set aside, if the arbitration agreement required reasons to be given Mr. Mukherjee cited the following judgments:

(i) Union of India vs. Singh Verma & Ors. reported in (1999) 3 CLT 354 (HC)
(ii) New India Civil Erectors (P) Ltd. vs. Oil and Natural Gas Commission reported in (1997) 11 SCC 75.

Mr. Mukherjee next submitted that the respondent had signed the final bill and accepted payment in full and final settlement of his claim. The respondent's claim was, therefore, barred under Clause 42(3) of the General Conditions of Contract. No arbitrable dispute thus existed and as such no further claim could be made. In support of his submission, Mr. Mukherjee cited the judgment of the Supreme Court in M/s. P.K. Ramaiya & Co. vs. Chairman & M.D., National Thermal Power Corporation reported in (1994) Suppl.3 SCC 126.

7

Mr. Mukherjee next submitted that the arbitrator was a creature of the contract and was thus bound by the terms and conditions of the contract. An arbitrator had no jurisdiction to make an award contrary to the express provisions of the contract and in particular Clause 16(2) read with Clauses 17(3) and 43(2) of the General Conditions of Contract.

Mr. Mukherjee argued that the learned arbitrator could not have awarded interest in view of the bar of Clause 16(2), which provides that the contractor might not claim interest for any amount due under the agreement.

In support of his submissions Mr. Mukherjee cited the following judgments:

1.Associated Engineering Co. Vs. Govt. of Andhra Pradesh reported in 1991 (4) SCC 93.
2. Executive Engineer, Dhenkanal Minor Irrigation Division, Orissa vs. N.C. Budharaj reported in AIR 2001 SC 626.
3. Rajasthan State Mines & Minerals reported in 1999 (9) SCC 283.

Mr. Moloy Kr. Ghosh, appearing on behalf of the respondents submitted that the petitioner having participated in the proceedings before the learned arbitrator was estopped from questioning the jurisdiction of the arbitrator, after the award went against the petitioner.

Mr. Ghosh argued that the award impugned was reasoned. The arbitrator had made a speaking award. The arbitrator was not required to give a detailed judgment. 8

Mr. Ghosh submitted that Clause 43 (2) of the General Conditions of Contract, 1969 provides that the contractor shall not be entitled to any claim whatsoever against the railway under or by virtue of or arising out of the contract, nor shall the railway entertain or consider such claim, if made by the contractor, if he shall have signed "no claim certificate"

in favour of the railway after the works are finally measured up.
Mr. Ghosh pointed out that a copy of the prescribed form of the contractor's "no claim certificate" as required by the Eastern Railway under Clause 43(2) of the General Conditions of Contract was tendered by the respondents before the learned arbitrator. The petitioner could not produce the no claim certificate in the format required under Clause 43(2). In other words, the petitioner was not able to prove that the respondent had signed the no claim certificate in the prescribed form, as required under Clause 43(2) of General Conditions of Contract, 1969.
Mr. Ghosh also argued that the ground taken by the petitioner regarding full and final settlement was without basis. As rightly argued by Mr. Ghosh the learned arbitrator was competent to adjudicate the factual issue of whether there had been a full and final settlement and whether the prohibition of Clause 43(2) of the General Conditions of Contract, 1969 was attracted. The issues were decided in favour of the respondent and against the petitioner on consideration of the materials on record including the provisions of the contract. This Court may not sit in appeal over the factual findings of the learned 9 arbitrator. The judgment in M/s. Ramaiya & Co. (supra) is distinguishable on facts in that there was a finding of full and final settlement.
Mr. Ghosh agreed that the arbitrator was bound by the contract. Mr. Ghosh, however, submitted that the interpretation of the contractual provisions was within the domain of the arbitrator and unless the interpretation was absurd, the Court would not interfere. Mr. Ghosh submitted that none of the claims allowed by the arbitrator were patently barred under the contract.
It is a matter of record that an independent arbitrator was appointed by an order dated 19 th July, 1996 passed in a Special Suit under Section 20 of the Arbitration Act, 1940. An appeal from the order of the Single Judge was dismissed in October, 1996. The petitioner did not appeal to the Supreme Court, but submitted to the jurisdiction of the arbitrator. The issue of competence of the arbitrator is barred by res judicata in view of the order of the Division Bench of 15th October, 1996 dismissing the appeal against the order appointing Mr. Gopal Chakravarty as arbitrator.
The said Gopal Chakravarty held about 185 sittings during his life time. The petitioner participated without demur. The present arbitrator also held about 18 sittings in which the petitioner participated without protest.
The petitioner accepted and acted upon the order dated 25th November, 2003 in G.A. No.3166 of 2003, whereby the present arbitrator was appointed. Having appeared before the 10 independent arbitrator, the petitioner is now estopped from contending that the appointment of the arbitrator was not in accordance with the contract.
As held by P.B. Mookerjee, J. in Jupitar General Insurance Co. Ltd. vs. Corporation of Calcutta reported in AIR 1956 Cal. 470, cited by Mr. Ghosh, a party participating in the arbitration proceedings without protest, cannot afterwards challenge the whole proceedings as without jurisdiction when the award goes against him. The same proposition was reiterated by the Supreme Court in Prasun Roy vs. Calcutta Metropolitan Development Authority reported in AIR 1988 SC 205, Neelkantan and Bros. Construction vs. S.E., National Highways reported in AIR 1988 SC 2045, Construction India vs. Secy., Works Deptt., Govt. of Orissa reported in AIR 1998 SC 717, Himalayan Construction Co. vs. Executive Engineer, Irrigation Division, J & K reported in AIR 2000 SC 3539 and Inder Sain Mittal vs. Housing Board, Haryana reported in (2002) 3 SCC 175 cited by Mr. Ghosh.
The judgment of the Supreme Court in Union of India vs. Krishna Kumar (supra) was rendered in an appeal arising out of an order under Section 34 of the Arbitration and Conciliation Act, 1996 upsetting the judgment of the learned Single Judge whereby the learned Single Judge had set aside the award.
In view of specific provisions of Sections 12 and 13 of the Arbitration and Conciliation Act, 1996, any objection to the jurisdiction of the learned arbitrator is to be raised before the learned arbitrator. If the arbitrator proceeds with the reference, the award 11 would have to be challenged under Section 34. The award of the arbitrator might be challenged on the ground of want of jurisdiction.
The judgment in Krishna Kumar (supra) was rendered in the particular facts of that case, in the context of the provisions of the Arbitration and Conciliation Act, 1996. From the judgement of the learned Single Judge, which was also cited before this Court, it appears that objection to the jurisdiction of the arbitrator had been taken before the learned arbitrator, but not sustained. The judgment has no application in this proceeding under the Arbitration Act, 1940.
In Kiran Singh & Ors. vs. Chaman Paswan & Ors.(supra) the Supreme Court inter alia held as follows:
"The answer to these contentions must depend on what the position in law is when a Court entertains a suit or an appeal over which it has not jurisdiction, and what the effect of section 11 of the Suits Valuation Act is on that position. It is a fundamental principle well-established that a decree passed by a Court without jurisdiction is a nullity, & that its invalidity could be set up whenever and wherever it is sought to be enforced or relied upon, even at the stage of execution and even in collateral proceedings. A defect of jurisdiction, whether it is pecuniary or territorial, or whether it is in respect of the subject- matter of the action, strikes at the very authority of the Court to pass any decree, and such a defect cannot be cured even by consent of parties. If the question now under consideration fell to be determined only on the application of general principles governing the matter, there can be no doubt that the District Court of Monghyr was coram non judice, and that its judgment and decree would be nullities. The question is what is the effect of section 11 of the Suits Valuation Act on this position."

The jurisdiction of Court cannot be equated with the jurisdiction of the arbitrator. While the jurisdiction of Court is created by statute, the arbitrator derives jurisdiction from 12 agreement. An agreement might be modified by the course of conduct of the parties. Thus, the defect in appointment of an arbitrator may be deemed to have been waived by continuous participation without objection.

The judgment of the Rajasthan High Court in Smt. Jeevani Bano vs. Smt. Asha Arora & Ors. (supra) was also rendered in the context of the jurisdiction of a Court of law. The Rajasthan High Court held that the objection to jurisdiction of Court could be raised at any stage.

In Tarapore & Co. (supra) the Supreme Court held as follows:

"The aforesaid are the rival contentions relating to jurisdiction. Before we express our views on this all important question, it deserves to be stated that if an authority would lack jurisdiction in the sense that the subject-matter is not amenable at all to its decision, i.e., the case be of patent lack of jurisdiction, acquiescence of the parties would not be material inasmuch as it is settled law that by agreement jurisdiction cannot be conferred. The present is, however, not such a case inasmuch as the arbitration clause, 4.3.29, reading as below:
"...any dispute as to the meaning or the specification, conditions etc. or as to the quality of materials, workmanship etc. or any other matter, thing, dispute or question whatsoever relating to or arising out of or in any way connected with the contract whether arising during the period of the contract or after the completion shall be referred to the Arbitration of two persons, one each to be nominated by either party to the dispute, the two Arbitrators so appointed selecting an Umpire."

Would show that any dispute relating to or arising out of or in any way connected with the contract has to be referred to arbitration. The present was definitely a dispute arising out of or connected with the contract. The subject-matter of the dispute is thus squarely covered by the arbitration clause and therefore we do not read parent lack of jurisdiction on the part of the arbitrators in having gone into the question of reimbursement. The best that could be said is that the terms of the agreement being what they are, the arbitrators had no jurisdiction to entertain the claim, and so, the present was a case of 13 latent lack of jurisdiction. In such a case acquiescence of the parties may be relevant."

The Supreme Court in effect found that where a dispute arose out of or was connected with the contract, and the subject-matter of the dispute was squarely covered by the arbitration clause, the defect in constitution of the Arbitral Tribunal could at best be said to be a case of latent lack of jurisdiction where acquiescence of the party might be relevant.

In Union of India vs. M.P. Gupta (supra), the Supreme Court was considering an appeal from an order of the Division Bench of the High Court whereby the Division Bench had dismissed an appeal from an order of the Single Bench appointing a retired Judge as arbitrator in contravention of Clause 64(3)(a)(ii) of the Contract, in terms whereof two arbitrators, who were gazetted railway officers of equal status were to be appointed in the manner laid down in Clause 64(3)(b), for all claims of Rs.5 lakhs and above, and for all claims irrespective of the amount, if the issues involved were of a complicated nature.

In M.P. Gupta (supra) the Supreme Court held that a retired Judge could not be appointed sole arbitrator, there being an express provision in the contract for appointment of two arbitrators. The parties had not participated in proceedings before the arbitrator.

The order in A. Mohammed Yunus vs. Food Corporation of India (supra) was passed in the particular facts of the case. The judgment does not lay down any binding precedent. The earlier judgments in Prasun Roy (supra) and other cases were also not considered. 14

"Reasons" have been defined in Union of India vs. M.L. Capoor reported in AIR 1974 SC 87 as submitted by Mr. Mukherjee. They are:
"The links between the materials on which certain conclusions are based and the actual conclusions. They disclose how the mind is applied to the subject matter for a decision whether it is purely administrative or quasi-judicial. They should reveal a rational nexus between the facts considered and the conclusions reached. Only in this way can opinions or decisions recorded be shown to be manifestly just and reasonable"

Although it is not necessary for the arbitrators to have a detailed judgment, as held in Singh Verma & Ors (supra) cited by Mr. Mukherjee, the reasons must be adequate, in the sense that they must deal with the points raised; intelligible, in the sense that the facts found must reasonably support the conclusion, and proper, in the sense that the conclusion must not be an illegal one.

The award of the learned Arbitrator is sufficiently reasoned and is based on his analysis of the materials and evidence on record. The arbitrator is not required to give detailed reasons as held by the Supreme Court in Indian Oil Corporation vs. Indian Carbon Ltd. reported in AIR 1988 SC 1340. Short intelligible reasons indicating the mind of the arbitrator, as in the instant case, would suffice.

It is a well-established proposition that this Court cannot scrutinize the reasonableness of the reasons given by the arbitrator. This proposition finds support from the judgment of the Supreme Court in Municipal Corporation of Delhi vs. M/s. Jagannath Ashok Kumar reported in AIR 1987 SC 2316.

15

Clause 16(2) of the General Conditions of Contract relied upon by Mr. Mukherjee fell for consideration in different Division Bench judgments of this Court. In Union of India vs. Royal Construction reported in (2002) 1 CHN 13, the Division Bench held that the said clause did not prohibit the arbitrator from granting interest. Similar view was taken in the judgment of the Division Bench dated 8th August, 2001 in G.A. No.3694 of 2000 (Union of India vs. Lovely Construction), which does not appear to have been reported.

In Union of India vs. Pam Development Pvt. Ltd. reported in AIR 2005 Cal. 332 the Division Bench held that notwithstanding Clause 16(2) the arbitrator has power to grant interest. It is true that in Union of India vs. Budhlani Engineering Pvt. Ltd. (2008 CWN (Vol. 112) 1195 a Division Bench presided over by Bhaskar Bhattacharya, J. has differed from the view taken in Pam Development (supra) and referred the issue of whether Clause 16(2) prohibits the arbitrator from granting interest to the Chief Justice for constitution of a larger Bench.

Be it noted that in Board of Trustees for the Port of Calcutta vs. Engineers-De- Space-Age reported in (1996) 1 SCC 516, cited by Mr. Ghosh, the Supreme Court held that a clause of the contract prohibiting the Commissioners from granting interest on account of delayed payment to the contractor was to be strictly construed. The Supreme Court found that the clause did not prohibit the arbitrator from awarding interest pendente lite. The Supreme Court held that the arbitrator had jurisdiction to interpret the clause of the contract, to decide whether pendente lite interest could be awarded by him thereunder. 16

The very fact that at least three Division Benches have taken the view that the arbitrator might award interest notwithstanding Clause 16(2) and other Division Benches have taken a different view, makes it clear that Clause 16(2) is capable of more than one interpretation.

The arbitrator has the authority to interpret the provisions of the contract based on his understanding of the law and the Court would not interfere with the interpretation unless the same was patently perverse, unreasonable, absurd, whimsical and shocked the conscience of the Court. If the arbitrator's interpretation of Clause 16(2) derives support from at least three Division Bench judgments, it cannot be said that the award of interest is so grossly erroneous or arbitrary as to warrant interference of this Court in an application for setting aside under Section 30 read with Section 33 of the Arbitration Act, 1940. This Court, in exercise of jurisdiction under Section 30 read with Section 33 of the Arbitration Act, 1940 does not sit in appeal over the award made by an arbitrator.

This application thus fails and is dismissed.

(Indira Banerjee, J.)
